mainPackage

Class Hero

  • java.lang.Object
    • mainPackage.Hero

  • public class Hero
extends java.lang.Object
    Hero class represent a hero that wants to solve a maze. For the first task, he has access only to neighbor cells and the size of the maze, to check if our hero is still on the board, or is not staying on a wall. He only go to where he can, according to the priority of directions and the number of pebbles (number of times the cell was visited) on that cell. For the second task, hero has access to whole map, hence breadth first search algorithm it is used to determine the shortest path.
    Author:
    razvan

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      (package private) class  Hero.NeighborCell
      NeighborCell class has data about a cell like a reference to that cell and the direction/orientation where the cell may be found.

    • Field Detail

      • maze

        private Maze maze
        A reference to the maze map. For the first task it is used only the size of the map and neighbor cells, and for the second task it is used the whole map.

      • position

        private Position position
        The position of the hero on the map.

      • orientation

        private Orientation orientation
        The orientation of the hero. Orientation is relative to board.

      • shortestPath

        private java.util.ArrayList<Direction> shortestPath
        The shortest path from enter portal to exit portal described using directions (e.g. LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN)

    • Method Detail

      • move

        public void move(Direction direction)
        Move the hero according to a direction given as parameter. If the hero cannot move to that direction, a message will be shown. Also, if the maze is not initialized, a message will be also shown. As implementation the hero first will turn left, right or back if necessary and then he will go forward. Finally, the cell where the hero stays will be marked as being visited.
        Parameters:
        direction - the direction where the hero will go.
        See Also:
        moveFront(), moveLeft(), moveRight(), moveBack()

      • moveRight

        private void moveRight()
        Move the hero to hero's right cell. First, the hero will turn right:
        • when our hero is looking to North, right cell will be to East
        • when our hero is looking to East, right cell will be to South
        • when our hero is looking to South, right cell will be to West
        • when our hero is looking to West, right cell will be to North
        Then, the hero will move forward.
        See Also:
        moveFront()

      • moveLeft

        private void moveLeft()
        Move the hero to hero's left cell. First, the hero will turn left:
        • when our hero is looking to North, left cell will be to WEST
        • when our hero is looking to East, left cell will be to NORTH
        • when our hero is looking to South, left cell will be to EAST
        • when our hero is looking to West, left cell will be to SOUTH
        Then, the hero will move forward.
        See Also:
        moveFront()

      • moveBack

        private void moveBack()
        Move the hero to hero's back cell. First, the hero will turn back:
        • when our hero is looking to North, back cell will be to SOUTH
        • when our hero is looking to East, back cell will be to WEST
        • when our hero is looking to South, back cell will be to NORTH
        • when our hero is looking to West, back cell will be to EAST
        Then, the hero will move forward.
        See Also:
        moveFront()

      • moveFront

        private void moveFront()
        Move the hero to the cell next to him. If the orientation of the hero is:
        • North - the position on Y will decrease
        • East - the position on X will increase
        • South - the position on Y will increase
        • West - the position on X will decrease
        If the hero tries to leave the board or tries to walk on a wall then an exception will be thrown and treated by showing a message.
        See Also:
        moveNorth(), moveEast(), moveSouth(), moveWest()

      • moveNorth

        private void moveNorth()
                throws HeroOutOfGroundException,
                       CannotMoveIntoWallsException
        The hero will move to North, this means that the Y coordinate of hero's position will decrease.
        Throws:
        HeroOutOfGroundException - when the hero tries to leave the ground
        CannotMoveIntoWallsException - when the hero tries to move into a wall

      • moveSouth

        private void moveSouth()
                throws HeroOutOfGroundException,

        The hero will move to South, this means that the Y coordinate of hero's position will increased.
        Throws:

        CannotMoveIntoWallsException - when the hero tries to move into a wall

      • aiMove

        public Direction aiMove()
        Compute the next direction where the hero will go. The algorithm is the following:
        1. Generate an array of neighbor cells that are not wall cells
        2. Sort the array according to the priority (number of times the cell was visited and direction priority)
        3. Return first element of the array
        Returns:
        the direction the hero will follow
        See Also:
        arrayOfNeighbors(), Hero.NeighborCell

      • arrayOfNeighbors

        private java.util.ArrayList<Hero.NeighborCell> arrayOfNeighbors()
        Create an array of cells that are PathCell (InPortalCell, OutPortalCell, FreeCell) in neighborhood of the cell where hero stays. Each element from the array is a NeighborCell instance, having a reference to that cell and here using the direction field (the direction where the cell is positioned according to the position of the hero).
        Returns:
        an array of NeighborCell elements.
        See Also:
        getCellDirection(Cell), Maze.getCellAt(int, int)

      • arrayOfNeighbors

        private java.util.ArrayList<Hero.NeighborCell> arrayOfNeighbors(Position pos)
        Create an array of cells that are PathCell (InPortalCell, OutPortalCell, FreeCell) in neighborhood of the cell dictated by a given position. Each element from the array is a NeighborCell instance, having a reference to that cell and here using the direction field (the direction where the cell is positioned according to the position given as argument).
        Parameters:
        pos - a position where to find neighbor cell
        Returns:
        an array of NeighborCell elements.
        See Also:
        getCellDirection(Cell), Maze.getCellAt(int, int)

      • getCellDirection

        private Direction getCellDirection(Cell cell)
        Get the direction of a cell according to the orientation of the hero.
        Parameters:
        cell - a cell
        Returns:
        the direction of the cell according to he orientation of the hero
        See Also:

      • getCellDirection

        private Direction getCellDirection(Orientation cellOrientation,
                                   Orientation baseOrientation)
        Get the direction of a cell according to the orientation of both cell, the reference and the other one, by calculating the difference of the indices of orientations in enumeration.
        Parameters:
        cellOrientation - orientation of a cell
        baseOrientation - orientation of base cell
        Returns:
        a direction where to find the cell, according the a base cell.

      • getCellOrientation

        private Orientation getCellOrientation(Cell cell)
        Get the orientation of a cell according to the position of the hero.
        Parameters:
        cell - any neighbor cell
        Returns:
        the orientation of the cell according to the position of the hero

      • computeShortestPath

        public void computeShortestPath()
        Compute the shortest path between InPortalCell and OutPortalCell using breadth first search algorithm. The maze is considered being a graph, or more precisely a tree of possibilities of getting the exit point. So, going through the tree in depth, any level being current position of the hero. The path described by this algorithm is one chosen to be the shortest path from all paths generated by this algorithm. The main idea of following the path is simple:
        1. compute the path using breadth first search algorithm
        2. for each orientation compute the direction to be followed
        3. update the orientation
        4. add the direction to the shortest path stored outside of the function
        See Also:
        breadthFirstSearch(), getCellDirection(Orientation, Orientation)

      • moveShortestPath

        public Direction moveShortestPath()
        Get next move from shortest path. If there don't exist any path, or the path is empty, null will be returned.
        Returns:
        return next move

      • breadthFirstSearch

        private java.util.ArrayList<Orientation> breadthFirstSearch()
        It uses the breadth first search algorithm to determine the shortest path to the exit portal. It uses a queue of possible cells to be visited (all possibilities in a current state), a set of visited cells and a hashmap for describing the way of getting to that cell. The algorithm is presented as follows:
        • Add first cell (from starting point) to the queue. There are no ways to get to the first cell, so data are null.
        • While we have cell inside the queue:
          • if last cell is OutPortalCell then construct the path and return the reverse.
          • for each neighbor of that cell:
            • if the cell was visited, go to next one
            • if that cell is not in the queue, add it and generate data to hashmap
          • mark last cell as being visited
        In other words, this algorithm generates all possible paths and while generating, when the first path gets to the final point, then that is the shortest one.
        Returns:
        the shortest path to the exit portal

      • constructPath

        private java.util.ArrayList<Orientation> constructPath(PathCell cell,
                                                       java.util.HashMap<PathCell,Hero.NeighborCell> cellData)
        Construct the path from exit portal to enter portal, using the data stored in a hashmap.
        Parameters:
        cell - last cell in the path
        cellData - data about getting to each cells form the path
        Returns:
        an array of orientations
